lines.text: Remember what the general said; we're the cavalry. It would be bad form to arrive in advance of schedule. In the nick of time would do nicely.
[last lines]
I've just been on to Monty. He's very proud and pleased.
Pleased?
Of course. He thinks Market Garden was 90% successful.
But what do you think?
Well, as you know, I always felt we tried to go a bridge too far.
35 hours tomorrow afternoon. The Irish Guards under the command of Col. Vandeleur will take the lead.

[sotto voce]
Christ, not us again.
What'd you say to that, Joe?
Delighted, sir, truly delighted.

I've selected you to lead us, not only because of your extraordinary fighting ability, but also because, in the unlikely event the Germans ever get you, they will assume from your attire that they've captured a wretched peasant and immediately send you on your way.
[an SS officer is approaching under a white flag]
Rather interesting development, sir.
[to the German]
That's far enough! We can hear you from there!
My general says there is no point in continuing this fighting! He wishes to discuss terms of a surrender!
Shall I answer him, sir?
Tell him to go to hell.
We haven't the proper facilities to take you all prisoner! Sorry!

[confused]
What?
We'd like to, but we can't accept your surrender! Was there anything else?
[German officer walks off]
Well, that's that.
[the officer returns to General Bittrich, and they converse in German]
They rejected our surrender offer. What are your orders, Herr General?
Flatten Arnhem.
I'm awfully sorry, but I'm afraid we're going to have to occupy your house.
This is a story you will tell your grandchildren; and mightily bored they'll be.

[looking at the escaped lunatics pointing and laughing at the British paratroops]
Think they know something we don't?
I'm Bobby Stout.
Have you ever been liberated before?
I got divorced twice, does that count?
That counts.
[Carlyle has asked to see Frost before he dies]
Hello, Harry.
Hello. Johnny.
You know, Harry; I always wanted to ask you, but didn't because I knew you so very much wanted me to and I didn't want to give you the satisfaction; but why do you always carry that umbrella?
Bad memory. Never could remember the password. Knew no Jerry would carry one. Had to prove I was an Englishman, you see.
Sergeant Dohun pulled a gun on me and threatened to kill me unless I did precisely what he ordered. I want you to put him under arrest.
Yes sir.
I want you to keep him there. I want you to keep him there for at least ten seconds.
I'm not all that sure I understand, Colonel.
Count to ten, Lieutenant, fast.
One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten. Like that, sir?

[dismisses him]
Thank you, Lieutenant.
Field Marshal, thousands of paratroops have landed in this area, three kilometres from here.
What? Why? There is nothing important here... me! I'm important! They must've landed here just to capture me.
[stands from his lunch and moves to the door]
Get my car ready.
[makes to leave]
Yes, sir!
[about to leave himself]

[pops back in and shouts]
And don't forget my cigars!
[Horrocks is about to brief his XXX Corps on Operation Market Garden]
Gentlemen, this is a story that you shall tell your grandchildren, and mightily bored they'll be.
[the entire corps laughs]
The plan is called "Operation Market Garden". "Market" is the airborne element, and "Garden", the ground forces. That's us.
[Horrocks points to a map behind him of Holland, showing the positions of the Allied forces, and the path the Corps will take]

Now, this is our position on the Belgian border, here. Tomorrow, three airborne divisions will begin landing in Holland. 35,000 men taking off from 24 airfields in troop-carrying planes or towed in gliders. The American 101st, here, around Eindhoven, the American 82nd, here, south of Nijmegen, and our own 1st airborne boys, and a Polish brigade, here, at Arnhem, 64 miles behind enemy lines.
[the corps murmurs at the details of the operation]

[Continuing with the briefing]
Now, their job is to take and hold all the bridges in these three areas. Our job is to punch a hole through the German front line, here, and then drive like hell up this road, linking up with each airborne division on the way. Speed is the vital factor. The plan is to reach Eindhoven in two to three hours, and Arnhem in two to three days. That, gentlemen, is the prize - the bridge over the Rhine, the last bridge between us and Germany. Kickoff will be at 1435 hours tomorrow afternoon. The Irish Guards, under the command of Colonel Vandeleur, will take the lead.

[whispering to his adjutant]
Christ, not us again.

[Hearing Vandeleur's statement to his adjutant]
What do you say to that, J.O.E?

[getting up from his chair and addressing General Horrocks]
Uh, delighted, sir. Truly delighted.
[the corps erupts in laughter again as Horrocks smiles. Vandeleur sits back down]

Now, I've selected you to lead us not only because of your extraordinary fighting ability, but also because in the unlikely event that the Germans ever get you, they will assume from your attire that they've captured a wretched peasant, and immediately send you on your way.
[the corps laughs at Horrocks' comments]

Now, maintaining the speed of our advance will no doubt be tough going, as it's a single highway. But no matter what, we must reach those 1st airborne boys in 48 hours. Now, gentlemen, I'm not saying that this will be the easiest party that we've ever attended, but I still wouldn't miss it for the world
[pauses]

I'd like to think of this as one of those American western films. The paratroops, lacking substantial equipment, always short of food - these are the besieged homesteaders, the Germans, well naturally, they're the bad guys, and XXX Corps, we my friends, are the cavalry, on the way to the rescue.
[the room bursts into applause]
[First lines]
[film opens with montage footage of a World War II era bomber dropping ordinances. Suddenly, the footage freezes, and we hear a woman speaking]
It's hard to remember now, but Europe was like this in 1944.
[the video resumes, showing footage of the fighting while the narrator continues on with the introduction]
The Second World War was in its fifth year and still going Hitler's way. German troops controlled most of Europe. D-Day changed all that.
[the archive footage cuts to the invasion of Normandy and the liberation of Paris]

D-Day, June 6, 1944, when the Allied forces, under their commander, General Eisenhower, landed on the northern coast of France. By July, they were able to begin their own offensive. By August, Paris was liberated. Everywhere the Germans retreated.
[we then see archive footage showing the Allied advance through northern France]
But with the Allied victories came problems. Supplies still had to be driven from Normandy, over 400 miles away, and became dangerously short. The Allied advance began to come to a halt.
[the archive footage then goes to video of General Eisenhower, General Patton, and Field Marshal Montgomery]

Another problem facing Eisenhower was this. His two most famous generals - Patton, who was in the south, and Montgomery in the north - disliked each other intensely. Their long-standing rivalry had never been more fierce. There simply were not enough supplies for both armies. Each wanted to be the one to defeat the Germans. Each wanted to beat the other to Berlin.
[we now see footage of the planning stages of "Operation Market Garden" as well as hear background music as the woman continues with the introduction]

In September 1944, Montgomery devised a new and spectacular plan code named "Market Garden". Eisenhower, under great pressure from his superiors, finally sided with Montgomery, and "Operation Market Garden" became a reality. The plan, like so many plans in so many wars before it, was meant to end the fighting by Christmas, and bring the boys back home.
[we see the archive footage freeze, and watch it zoom in on General Eisenhower before fading to black]
Sir.
[Offers mug of tea]

Hancock. I've got lunatics laughing at me from the woods. My original plan has been scuppered now that the jeeps haven't arrived. My communications are completely broken down. Do you really believe any of that can be helped by a cup of tea?
Couldn't hurt, sir.
[Urquhart accepts his mug of tea]
So that's it. We're pulling them out. It was Nijmegen.
It was the single road getting to Nijmegen.
No, it was after Nijmegen.
And the fog, in England.
Doesn't matter what it was. When one man says to another, "I know what let's do today, let's play the war game."... everybody dies.
Hello, Roy. How are you?
I'm not sure I'll know for a while. But I'm sorry about how it turned out.
You did all you could.
Yes, but did everyone else?
They've got a bed for you upstairs if you want it.
I took ten thousand men into Arnhem. I've come out with less than two. I don't feel much like sleeping.
[Before jumping out of a plane]
God bless Field Marshal Montgomery.
I thought everyone knew that God was a Scotsman.
Where's the captain?
Dead.
Didn't ask you how he was. I asked you where he was.
Joe? Joe, how the hell do they expect us to keep schedule on a road like this?
You don't know the worst. This bit we're on now?
Yes?
It's the wide part.
Do you think you'll be able to pull it off, Joe?
I have nothing else planned for this afternoon.
Could you get a message down to XXXth Corps on that dingus?
Yes, sir. Uh, we just got word from the 82nd up ahead. They captured the Graves bridge completely intact!
Aw, that's terrrific. Except XXXth Corps ain't about to reach the godam intact Graves bridge until the godam Son bridge gets fixed. Tell our British cousins to hustle up some Bailey stuff.
Yes, sir.
I'll meet 'em in Eindoven when they get there. Tell those schmucks to do this right and have their Bailey stuff at the front of their column. Got that?
Yes, sir.
And be sure to say please.
Yes, sir.
You scared the shit out of me, you stupid bastard.
You did a fine job yourself, sir, if it makes you feel any better.
You're goddamn right it does.
Forgive me, but there is a battle. And we are in the process of winning it.
Winning and losing is not our concern - living and dying... is.

[reporting another delay to his officers]
Ah, I suppose you're wondering why I called you here. I want to tell you that I've decided to cross the river like George Washington; standing in the prow of the boat.
Yes, thousands of paratroopers have landed in Nijmegen... right on top of Field Marshal Model.
I'll bet they landed in his soup!
You'd like that, wouldn't you?
Those are British troops at Arnhem. They're hurt bad. And you're just gonna sit here... and... drink tea?
[after the fighting is over, Bittrich rides in to meet the English captives. He sees Frost, who is sitting on the ground with a leg injury. He offers a bar of chocolate and says something in German]
My general says, please take it. It's very good chocolate. Your planes dropped it to us yesterday.
[Frost waits a few moments, then takes the chocolate]
English?
[Frost nods]
[Bittrich listens in amazement as Frost's troops relentlessly storm the Arnhem bridge]

[in German]
Fool's courage...
Let's get to the point. Air power?
Air power, Field Marshal...
Briefly, please.
Air power is minimal.
Ammunition?
Also minimal.
Tanks, troops, replacements?
Minimal.
Morale?
[Blumentritt hesitates, then says nothing]

[sighs]
Nonexistent.
Why do all my generals want to destroy my bridges?

[to Home Owner]
I'm terrible sorry about all this, you know.
[repeated line]
Hail Mary full of grace... Hail Mary full of grace...
What can you see?
Nothing. But they're going to try a river assault.
It will fail.
Of course. But what do we do if it doesn't?
What's the best way to take a bridge?
Both ends at once.
I'm sending two companies across the river by boat. I need a man with very special qualities to lead.
Go on, sir.
He's got to be tough enough to do it and he's got to be experienced enough to do it. Plus one more thing. He's got to be dumb enough to do it... Start getting ready.
What was all that about, Major?
Well someone's come up with a real nightmare. Real nightmare.
Everyone knows you have never lost a battle.
I'm still young, give me time.
She says you are much too noisy.
She does realize there's something of a war going on, doesn't she?

When you first named me to this command, I told you I had never jumped before, but I felt I should at least give it a go. You told me, 'Roy, you're much too old and far too large for that sort of thing.' Well, I didn't tell you at the time, but you did me a favor. You see, I'm prone to airsickness.
Good God. Every time?
Well, we'll soon see.
[Stout and Vanderleur are discussing how to get the Bailey bridge through town]
When you refer to Bailey crap I take it you mean that glorious, precision-made, British-built bridge which is the envy of the civilized world?
[looks at the crowd of Dutch civilians]
I don't know how you're going to get it through this crowd.
No sweat. I got a back way staked out that will avoid all this. American ingenuity.
Really?
Actually, I was born in Yugoslavia, but what the hell.
[final plans are being discussed]
Only the weather can stop us now.
Weather. What of the Germans, General Browning. Don't you think that if we know Arnhem is so critical to their safety that they might know it too?
See here, General Sosaboski, I should think you would have more faith in Field Marshal Montgomery's plan.
Faith? I will tell you how much faith I have. I am thinking of asking for a letter from you stating that I was ordered to go on this mission in case my men are massacred.
I see... I do see. Do you wish such a letter?
what difference will it make?
[Gavin is discussing the glitches that have come up]
I don't want to hear any more. Is there any more?
You're my Dutch advisor, Harry.
What's that supposed to mean?
Just that the Germans first tried to take Nijmeagen Bridge in 1940; and got slaughtered.
No reinforcements to Arnhem. Von Runstedt says we will need them for our counter attack.
Counterattack! With what?
Paratroopers are lightly armed and equipped. They cannot hold out for long. If we can hold up their infantry on the road to Arnhem, they will be forced to surrender.
My problem is, I'm not totally crazy about the prospect of dying.
So don't die. Drinking that garbage isn't gonna keep you alive, is it?
What is?
What is? Well, not gettin' shot.
What can guarantee that?
Nothing, for sure.
You will.
I will what?
You tell me, Eddie. You tell me I won't die.
Alright, you won't die.
No, no. Guarantee me. I want you to guarantee me I won't die.

[seriously]
I guarantee you.
Colonel, if you don't look at him right now, he's going to die.
He's dead now.
It would mean a lot to me, sir, if you'd check him out.
Come on, Sergeant! For Chrissakes get him out of here!
Would you look at him please, sir.
[draws his .45]
Right now. Or I'll blow your fuckin' head off.
[cocks the .45]
Right now.
I can give him a quick examination if you like.
Thank you very much, sir.
Morphine! Taffy, I must have morphine!
Morphine's only for the people who are really hurt.
I thought I *was* really hurt.
Well, you're wrong.
